channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #192 - The YAPC::NA schedule is out!
item.description:
Hi,

The schedule for YAPC::NA is out and there are tons for good-looking talks!

Talking of talks, today's your last chance to submit something for the German Perl workshop.

Editor #3, Neil
item.dc:subject: list of tags?

item.title: Perl Developer - Teleperformance - Grandview Heights, Ohio (Columbus)
item.description: Teleperformance is looking for talented Perl developers who are eager to join our team (10 developers).Â We are a close-knit development group who live and breathe Perl and the open source philosophy.Â We are located in Grandview Heights, Ohio, with easy access to the downtown area.

item.title: InsideSales.com - Pass our "Perl Challenge" & Win a $100 Amazon Gift Card
item.description: Our yummy Perl codebase handles millions of emails in production each week! We're growing like crazy, doubling in revenue and size annually. We want you to join our team in Utah. Pass our "Perl Challenge" to win a $100 Amazon gift card and an interview. Hires will receive a sizable signing bonus.

item.title: Work for Uniregistry, building and maintaining Internet new Top Level Domains
item.description: Use Moose, DBIx::Class, Catalyst, AnyEvent and work in an dream office in Newport Beach office in California to Â build and maintain our registry platform and services for Internet new Top Level Domains (nTLDs). Send your CV to jobs@uniregistry.link

item.title: File::Which, pwhich and App::pwhich
item.description: Graham has recently adopted File::Which and posted about his plans for the module, in particular splitting out the pwhich script into a separate distribution, to minimise the dependencies for the main module.

item.title: Nestoria's module of the month: Web::Query
item.description: This month Nestoria tip their hat to Web::Query, a module for processing a web page in a jQuery stylee. Originally written by TOKUHIROM, but currently maintained by YANICK.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Calculate Fortune's Formula with Perl
item.description: David introduces the Kelly criterion, a formula used to calculate what percentage of your bank you should stake. He's released Algorithm::Kelly to Kelly, if you're interested. The Kelly criterion is widely used by betting types (my missus and I used the Kelly criterion in the horse-betting system we ran a few years back. Not that we're betting types. Any more).

item.title: New stable and development Catalyst releases
item.description: John describes what's in the latest Catalyst releases. The dev release is codenamed Australorp, named after an Australian chicken breed!

item.title: CA SSL HTTPs heck
item.description: Getting to the bottom of a problem with Amazon AWS. TL;DR: make sure Mozilla::CA is up to date.

item.title: Three articles on Modern Perl web apps
item.description: Dave has shared three articles that he wrote in 2011, about writing a Modern Perl web app using DBIx::Class and Dancer.

item.title: Faster DBIC Schemata
item.description: Frew shares some tips on how to get DBIC schema to load faster.

item.title: Gzipping data directly from Perl
item.description: brian shares some of the ways you can work with gzip'd data in Perl, for example via the recently updated PerlIO::gzip, or using pipes.

item.title: Interacting with PAUSE using CLI
item.description: Perlancar demonstrates his WWW::PAUSE::Simple module and associated pause script, which can be used to manage your PAUSE account from the command-line.

item.title: Howto: XS Coverage Reports on coveralls.io
item.description: Nick shows how authors of XS modules can get Devel::Cover and coveralls.io to play together nicely with Travis.

item.title: Rebuilding Cleveland Perl Mongers
item.description: The Cleveland Perl mongers have risen from the ashes like a Phoenix; StylusEater shared some of their journey.

item.title: YAPC::NA schedule
item.description: GENEHACK tweeted to announce that the schedule for YAPC::NA 2015 has been posted.

item.title: German Perl Workshop 2015: CFP extended until March 30th 2015
item.description: The German Perl workshop runs from the 6th to the 8th of May. If you're quick, you can still submit a talk proposal.

item.title: Sydney.PM April meeting
item.description: The Sydney mongers are meeting 14th April, and looking for speakers.

item.title: Promoting your Perl workshop or conference?
item.description: Gabor has put together a page with some tips for promoting your Perl event.

item.title: Perl 6 weekly happenings
item.description: Lazy deserialization of objects has been re-enabled in MoarVM, which should give "much better memory usage and speed when starting up a program that doesnâ€™t use every class there is". Also a rakudo release, some documentation improvements, and a bunch of other things too!

item.title: A public service announcement about contracts
item.description: Some excellent advice from Mark, about the right response when someone asks you to sign a contract with a clause that's only there because the lawyers wanted it. He followed it up with some examples.

item.title: Ruby survey results
item.description: A survey of Ruby developers, which has been running since 2008. I like that for many questions it shows how the answers have changed over the years. TL;DR: vim is the most popular way to edit Ruby.

item.title: The social coding contract
item.description: A talk from RubyConf last year, with lots of interesting observations of open source. I feel like I need to watch it again before I can distil it down any!

item.title: Sending Tweets from a Perl script
item.description: In this article full of screenshots you'll see how to write a Perl script to send messages via Twitter.

item.title: Getting started - Create skeleton for the SCO clone application
item.description: A screencast in which Gabor shows the first step in creating a clone of the search.cpan.org web site using PSGI and MetaCPAN as the back-end.

item.title: Counter Examples
item.description: The beginning of a series of articles showing how to write a counter with various front-ends (e.g. command line, web) and various back-ends (plain text file, MongoDB, etc.)
